div.p: Social network interference induces spillover effects from neighbors' exposures, and the complexity of statistical analysis increases when mediators are involved with network interference. To address various technical challenges, we develop a theoretical framework employing a structural graphical modeling approach to investigate both mediation and interference effects within network data. Our framework enables us to capture the multifaceted mechanistic pathways through which neighboring units' exposures and mediators exert direct and indirect influences on an individual's outcome. We extend the exposure mapping paradigm in the context of a random-effects network structural equation models (REN-SEM), establishing its capacity to delineate spillover effects of interest. Our proposed methodology contributions include maximum likelihood estimation for REN-SEM and inference procedures with theoretical guarantees. Such guarantees encompass consistent asymptotic variance estimators, derived under a non-i.i.d. asymptotic theory. The robustness and practical utility of our methodology are demonstrated through simulation experiments and a real-world data analysis of the Twitch Gamers Network Dataset, underscoring its effectiveness in capturing the intricate dynamics of network-mediated exposure effects. This work is the first to provide a rigorous theoretical framework and analytic toolboxes to the mediation analysis of network data, including a robust assessment on the interplay of mediation and interference.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The theory of mediation analysis can become highly intricate when experiment units are sampled from a network, a context in which limited statistical theory and methods have been explored in the literature. Consider a set of N units, often referred to as nodes and denoted by V, that forms a network within which each pair is linked by an edge if a connection exists between the two nodes. The between-node connections are described by an N √ó N adjacency matrix E. In this paper, we focus on a first-order Markov network structure, meaning that only immediate first-degree neighbors have a direct connection to a given unit. As a result, E is a binary matrix, where E ij = 1 if i th and j th nodes are connected (two units are directly connected by sharing a common edge) and E ii = 1 and E ij = 0 otherwise. To characterize the contiguity of a network, we denote the set of direct neighbors (or the first-degree adjacent neighbors) of unit i by N ‚Ä† i = {j | j Ã∏ = i and E ij = 1}, and the resulting unit-i-centric community is given by N i = N ‚Ä† i ‚à™ {i}. Each node in Figure 1 contains a Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG) clique consisting of three variables: A i , M i , and Y i .

Here Y i represents a continuous outcome, M i denotes a continuous mediator, and A i signifies a binary exposure, with their respective supports being Supp(Y i ) ‚äÜ R, Supp(M i ) ‚äÜ R, and Supp(A i ) = {0, 1}. For simplicity, let the vector C i include all confounders, either continuous or categorical, that may affect the three relationships of the underlying DAG pathway: between exposure and outcome (A ‚Üí Y ), between exposure and mediator (A ‚Üí M ), and between mediator and outcome (M ‚Üí Y ). Let dim(C) = p. Throughout this work, we restrict our attention to a binary exposure A and a one-dimensional mediator M .

In the classical theory of mediation analysis, the primary focus lies in estimation of the so-called natural direct effect (NDE) and natural indirect effect (NIE) of an exposure A on an outcome Y , where NIE is mediated through M . Typically, NDE marks the direct pathway A ‚Üí Y while NIE characterizes the mediation pathway A ‚Üí M ‚Üí Y . The seminal work by Baron and Kenny (1986) laid out the essential steps for establishing mediation, providing a foundational framework that has guided numerous subsequent studies. Building on this, Robins and Greenland (1992) pioneered the formal examination of causal mediation analysis, setting the stage for a rapidly expanded body of research that includes many influential contributions by Pearl (2001); Robins (2003); Rubin (2004); VanderWeele (2008VanderWeele ( , 2009)); Imai et al. (2010), among others. See more references in Ding (2024). Most of the existing works have focused on independently sampled units (or all E ij = 0) in which the so-called spillover effects are absent and irrelevant.

In the case of network data considered in the present paper, a significant technical challenge arises due to mutual influences and interferences between network-connected units. Interference occurs when the treatment, exposure, or intervention applied to one unit may have an extended influence to the response variable of one or more connected neighboring units, a unique phenomenon emerged from social or physical interactions among units. Such effect, known as spillover effect, gives rise to a different type of pathway, denoted by A N ‚Ä† i ‚Üí Y i for target unit i. This may become more complicated when self or neighborhood mediators are involved in the cross-node interplay. For instance, in Figure 1, altering the exposure A 2 of Unit 2 leads to a spillover effect on the outcome Y 1 of Unit 1 due to the network connection between units 1 and 2. Of note, this spillover effect is absent in the classical mediation analysis due to independence among units. Thus, this phenomenon requires developing new estimands, identifiability conditions, and analytics for a serious exploration theoretically and numerically. An oversight of spillover effects in the analysis can distort the understanding of how exposures and mediators influence outcomes within a network.

Traditional causal inference methods, which operate under the Stable Unit Treatment Value Assumption (SUTVA, Rubin (1980)), assume no hidden variations in treatment and thus preclude spillover effects (Sacerdote, 2001;Miguel and Kremer, 2004;Bakshy et al., 2012) in the analysis. In effect, the issue of interference has recently received a good deal of attention in the literature. Most of recent research on this topic has focused largely on methods in randomized trials collecting subjects from networks to study both direct effect and spillover effect (Hudgens and Halloran, 2008;Tchetgen and VanderWeele, 2012;Manski, 2013;Aronow and Samii, 2017;Leung, 2020;S√§vje et al., 2021;Hu et al., 2022). For example, Ogburn et al. (2022) investigated semiparametric estimation and inference for causal effects using observational data from a single social network while introduced some new causal estimands that are particularly relevant in social network settings. Tchetgen Tchetgen et al. (2021) developed innovative statistical methodologies for causal inference within the context of interference with no assumption of outcome independence among non-overlapping clusters such as a single interconnected network. Recent studies by Manski (2013), Aronow and Samii (2017), and Leung and Loupos (2022) utilized the concept of exposure mapping to define effective treatment due to neighbors, thereby aiding in the identification of causal effects under interference. Moreover, Sweet (2019) and Liu et al. (2021) proposed mediation models that incorporate social networks as mediators to explore the potential mediation role of these networks.

Despite these advancements, no existing statistical theory and methods have addressed the challenge of defining a unified framework for comprehensively studying the full spectrum of various effects involving both mediators and network interference. This is because the holistic approach is technically complex involving a great deal of nuance. To fill such a significant technical gap, this paper aims to advance the field by introducing a rigorous holistic theoretical framework designed specifically to establish and analyze the mechanistic pathways that involve both mediators and network-connected units simultaneously. The resulting comprehensive analytic enables to understand the joint effects of mediation and network interference, thereby enhancing applicability and capacity of causal inference in network data settings.

To address this technical need of analyzing spillover effects and increase the capacity of causal inference in a network setting, we propose a new linear random effects network structural equation model (REN-SEM) by extending the existing Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG) framework in Section 2.2. As a result, this new REN-SEM can account for both the direct and indirect influences of neighboring units' exposures and mediators on a target individual's outcome. This added capacity gives practitioners an opportunity to explore multifaceted channels of causal effects through which both self and neighboring exposure variables may impact a target outcome via self and/or neighboring mediators, all warranted under the network contiguity. In Section 2.3, we extend the concept of exposure mapping to explicitly and accurately delineate various spillover effects within the REN-SEM formulation. After introducing different mediation and interference estimands in addition to the classical NDE and NIE, we impose and discuss the necessary identifiability assumptions for the identification of all the estimands under investigation in Section 3. We present the identification theorem to estimate the proposed mediation and interference estimands using available data in Section 4. In Section 5, we present a rigorous theoretical foundation along with asymptotic results and consistent variance estimators for the proposed REN-SEM using large-sample techniques of dependent data. Furthermore, in Section 6, we conduct extensive simulation experiments to evaluate finite-sample performances of the proposed statistical methods for the estimation of various estimands, including the coverage probability to illustrate the validity of the proposed large-sample inference. Section 7 illustrates our proposed methodology by a study of gaming behaviors using the Twitch Gamers Social Network dataset, and Section 8 provides some concluding remarks. Most technical details are included in the Supplementary Material.

div.head: Mediation and Interference Pathways
div.p: It follows from equation ( 6) that in the REN-SEM potential outcome Y i (.) is a function of (A i , S A 1i , S A 2i , S A 3i ), as shown in Figure 3. It is challenging in terms of both administrative and financial resources to simultaneously intervene on exposures in practice in multiple communities. A realistic task is to focus on investigating the total effects of self and first-degree neighborhood exposures on the outcome through D i = (A i , S A 1i ) by marginalizing the other higher order aggregated exposures of (S A 2i , S A 3i ). Consequently, we shall focus on the spillover effect of first-degree neighborhood exposures on the outcome solely through S A 1i , the average number of first-degree neighboring units receiving the treatment. Such task targets at the estimands of primary interest in practice, facilitating the identification, feasibility and robustness in the analysis of causal mediation and interference effects, so that results enjoy interpretability.

To elucidate this point, let us consider our motivating data example in Section 7 with the platform primarily focusing on video gaming, including playthroughs, eSports broadcasts, and other gaming-related events. Within the network, each node represents a Twitch user while edges between nodes indicate mutual following relationships among users. A triple of variables measured on each node includes (i) a binary exposureA ‚àà {0, 1} with A = 1 indicates a user having mature content in light of explicit language, sexual content, graphic violence, or other adult themes, and A = 0 otherwise; (ii) a continuous mediator M representing the lifetime of user's account; and (iii) a continuous outcome Y as the number of views on the user's account. We want to assess how content maturity and network dynamics can influence viewership within the Twitch social network. To do this, node-level DAGs are imposed to study the mechanistic impact of maturity content-both of an individual and their network friends' average-on a user's account views, which may be potentially mediated by the account lifetime of both the individual and their neighbors.

div.head: Fixed Effects and Random Effects
div.p: In the utility of the proposed REN-SEM framework to study mechanistic pathways, we focus essentially on populationlevel fixed effects, instead of unit-specific random effects. Having such a focus is crucial, as it prevents the conflation of random variation and / or potential shrinkage with the six causal estimands, thereby providing robust inference and interpretable results about the population-level impacts of exposures on outcomes within the studied population.

Technically, to obtain the six estimands (œÑ 1 through œÑ 6 ) as fixed effects, we integrate over the random intercepts in the REN-SEM specified by equations ( 2) and (3). Of note, these random intercepts are included in the model primarily to capture dependencies and unobserved unit level heterogeneity among the mediators and outcomes within the network.
In this way, we hope to further address unit-specific variations that are beyond what observed variables can explain.

It is interesting to note that in the REN-SEM framework with only random intercepts, the magnitudes of causal estimands conditioned on random effects are not directly influenced by these random effects. This phenomenon results from the cancellation of random intercepts through a difference between two expectations in the derivation, effectively nullifying their impact within the linear mixed effects model framework adopted by REN-SEM. Apparently, this cancellation would not hold if random slopes were included in the model. It is important to point that random intercepts do not directly alter the estimands, they impact the second moments-specifically, the variance and covariance structures of M and Y . Such effects in turn, have non-ignorable influences for the statistical inference of the fixed effects in the REN-SEM.

div.head: Statistical Theory with Network-Dependent Data
div.p: As mentioned above, the six estimands œÑ 1 through œÑ 6 of interest are inherently functions of the parameters of the REN-SEM model in ( 2)-( 4) and are random effects free. div.head: Large Sample Properties

div.head: Analysis of the Gamer's Friendship Network
div.p: We now illustrate our methodology through the social network data of Twitch users, which is sourced from the public API in Spring 2018, as documented by (Rozemberczki and Sarkar, 2021). The friendship network is structured with nodes representing Twitch users (or gamer) and edges denoting mutual follower relationships between them, so they are conveniently referred to as friends in the data analysis. The total dataset comprises 168,114 nodes or gamers, but a subset of 1,415 nodes used in our analysis due purely to the computational costs. As discussed in Section 3, our primary focus is to apply our proposed methodology to assess the impact of mature content-both from individual users and the average within their network neighbors-on the views received by a user's account. This relationship is further analyzed for potential mediation by the account lifetime of both the individual user and their neighboring nodes (or friends). In the dataset analyzed, the average network degree is observed to be 67. Approximately 50% of the gamers' accounts are flagged for having mature content. The average account lifetime within our sample is 2,035 days, with a standard deviation of 730 days, indicating a substantial variation in the duration that accounts have been active. The average number of views per user's account stands at approximately 573,003 with a standard deviation of 227,498, highlighting significant disparities in viewership across different accounts. This dataset provides a rich framework for investigating how content maturity and network characteristics influence user engagement on the Twitch platform.

Our analysis results are summarized as follows. Supplementary Figure S2 presents the estimates of the six causal estimands along with 95% confidence intervals (C.I.s). Below are several findings in terms of the influence of maturity on viewer engagement.

This phenomenon might occur because the reduced lifetime of friend's accounts lessens competition for viewers, thereby channeling more traffic to the user's account. The negative direct and spillover effects highlight challenges in attracting viewers to mature content, while the positive mediated effects through neighbors' account lifetimes offer insights into potential strategies for mitigating these challenges.

div.head: Concluding Remarks
div.p: We have developed a substantial extension with full theoretical rigor to a conceptual framework of great importance to study mediation DAGs in a network setting. The proposed methodology enables to investigate mechanistic pathways beyond the classical natural direct and indirect effects based on independent units. Such extension is specifically relevant to the context of network-based data in social sciences, environmental health, epidemiology, and infectious disease. Our methodology, grounded in a comprehensive system of correlated Directed Acyclic Graphs (DAGs) and network structural equation models with random effects (i.e. REN-SEM), has identified six fundamental mediation and interference estimands, some of which, e.g. spillover effects, emerge exclusively due to the presence of network contiguity. Presenting a full spectrum of the six estimands is essential for a detailed exploration of causal effects in complex network systems where neighboring units can play a critical role in the study of mediation mechanisms on individual units.

One of the key technical contributions in this paper pertains to the rigorous specification of the identifiability conditions necessary to differentiate direct, mediation, spillover, and spillover mediation causal pathways in the proposed network structural equation models. We have rigorously established key regularity conditions that ensure consistent estimation and have derived extended asymptotic normality results under network-dependent units. These theoretical results have been illustrated with high robustness and reproducibility through empirical simulation studies, which confirm its applicability in practice. In particular, the empirical coverage probability by the constructed confidence interval for each of the six estimands is stably close to the nominal level across the majority of simulation settings, which enhances the trust of the proposed inference to be used in practical studies. The application of our methodology to the Twitch Dataset has elucidated some new mediation and spillover pathways in the understanding of gamer's behaviors such as streaming platform interact and influence user engagement and viewership patterns.

Despite these advancements, several limitations of our proposed methodology warrant further investigation. First, like the existing causal mediation analysis, the causal identification assumptions we have relied on may be susceptible to violations due to unobserved confounders, potentially complicating causal interpretations. This challenge remains an open problem in the field of causal inference and merits ongoing exploration. Second, our proposed REN-SEM modeling approach employs only random intercepts to account for network dependencies and unit-specific heterogeneity. Future work could extend the REN-SEM framework to incorporate random slopes, so to capture individual-level covariate effects. Additionally, expanding the REN-SEM model to include non-linear terms or to allow non-normal distributions would enhance its flexibility and practical impact, making it more adaptable to a wider range of applications.
